<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three new metal–organic supramolecular complexes based on the linking unit 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L) and inorganic Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> salts have been prepared and structurally determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis. Using L to react with Mn(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O yielded a mononuclear molecule, [Mn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (triclinic, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>−1, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=8.790(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=10.227(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=23.255(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>=89.371(8)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=82.980(8)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>=88.621(8)°, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=2), in which the hydrogen bonding and π–π aromatic stacking interactions extend the complex molecules to result in a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular network. Reaction of L and FeCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in the presence of NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN, afforded another mononuclear complex, [Fe(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NSC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (triclinic, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>−1, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=7.985(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=8.657(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=11.334(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>=94.243(6)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=109.989(7)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>=94.413(7)°, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=1). A 3D framework is observed through hydrogen bonds and π–π stacking co-affections between the complex molecules. Additionally, a 1D coordination polymer, [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) (triclinic, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>−1, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=8.321(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=13.926(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=14.229(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>=70.801(7)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=77.216(7)°, <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>=81.299(7)°, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=2) was obtained when AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> was used in the above reaction. The structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains significant aromatic interactions, which bind the infinite chains together to form a 2D layer network.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new metal-organic supramolecular complexes based on the linking unit 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L) and inorganic MnII, FeII, AgI salts have been prepared and structurally determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis. Using L to react with Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O yielded a mononuclear molecule, [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2 (1) (triclinic, P-1, a=8.790(4)Å, b=10.227(4)Å, c=23.255(10)Å, α=89.371(8)°, β=82.980(8)°, γ=88.621(8)°, Z=2), in which the hydrogen bonding and π-π aromatic stacking interactions extend the complex molecules to result in a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular network. Reaction of L and FeCl2⋅4H2O, in the presence of NH4SCN, afforded another mononuclear complex, [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2) (triclinic, P-1, a=7.985(3)Å, b=8.657(3)Å, c=11.334(4)Å, α=94.243(6)°, β=109.989(7)°, γ=94.413(7)°, Z=1). A 3D framework is observed through hydrogen bonds and π-π stacking co-affections between the complex molecules. Additionally, a 1D coordination polymer, [Ag2(L)2](BF4)2(CH3OH)0.5(H2O)0.5 (3) (triclinic, P-1, a=8.321(3)Å, b=13.926(5)Å, c=14.229(5)Å, α=70.801(7)°, β=77.216(7)°, γ=81.299(7)°, Z=2) was obtained when AgBF4 was used in the above reaction. The structure of 3 contains significant aromatic interactions, which bind the infinite chains together to form a 2D layer network.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Self-assembly processes involving metal ions and organic ligands have attracted ever-increasing attention in the area of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering from the viewpoints of the development of novel functional materials with desired properties . One of the ultimate goals of supramolecular chemistry is to predictably control the network structure, and thus to further modify the physicochemical property of the target product. The selection of proper ligands as ‘building blocks’, such as the simple 4,4′-bipyridyl-based ligands, is undoubtedly a key point in manipulating the network structures , and other factors such as the selection of the metal ion, the counter-anion and solvent effect have also been systematically studied by chemists in the past decade .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assembly processes involving metal ions and organic ligands have attracted ever-increasing attention in the area of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering from the viewpoints of the development of novel functional materials with desired properties . One of the ultimate goals of supramolecular chemistry is to predictably control the network structure, and thus to further modify the physicochemical property of the target product. The selection of proper ligands as ‘building blocks', such as the simple 4,4'-bipyridyl-based ligands, is undoubtedly a key point in manipulating the network structures , and other factors such as the selection of the metal ion, the counter-anion and solvent effect have also been systematically studied by chemists in the past decade .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">A novel angular dipyridyl-donor ligand, 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="SC1"></ce:float-anchor>), and its 3-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor analog 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L′), have been of our research interest  for their particular characteristics described as following. (a) These ligands can take versatile bonding modes, such as monodentate (using one pyridyl nitrogen donor), bidentate bridging (using two pyridyl nitrogen donors), and tridentate bridging (using two pyridyl and one oxadiazole nitrogen donors) coordination modes to construct diverse coordination frameworks. (b) The structural geometries of the ligands themselves are changeful. The dihedral angles between the oxadiazole ring and two pyridyl rings, as well as the angle between the center of the oxadiazole ring and two pyridyl nitrogen donors, are adaptable to meet the coordination requirements. (c) The aromatic groups in each ligand, including two pyridyl rings and the central oxadiazole system, usually show a tendency to completely or partly participate in intermolecular π–π interactions, which may significantly affect the packing arrangements of the structures. As a continuation of our work, we describe the preparation and structural characterization of three new complexes based on 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), [Mn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Fe(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NSC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), in the present contribution. The non-covalent intermolecular contacts, such as π–π stacking interactions and/or hydrogen bonds, are presented in these complexes, and their effects on the overall supramolecular architectures are discussed in detail.</ce:para>

(a) These ligands can take versatile bonding modes, such as monodentate (using one pyridyl nitrogen donor), bidentate bridging (using two pyridyl nitrogen donors), and tridentate bridging (using two pyridyl and one oxadiazole nitrogen donors) coordination modes to construct diverse coordination frameworks. (b) The structural geometries of the ligands themselves are changeful. The dihedral angles between the oxadiazole ring and two pyridyl rings, as well as the angle between the center of the oxadiazole ring and two pyridyl nitrogen donors, are adaptable to meet the coordination requirements. (c) The aromatic groups in each ligand, including two pyridyl rings and the central oxadiazole system, usually show a tendency to completely or partly participate in intermolecular π-π interactions, which may significantly affect the packing arrangements of the structures. As a continuation of our work, we describe the preparation and structural characterization of three new complexes based on 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2 (1), [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2) and [Ag2(L)2](BF4)2(CH3OH)0.5(H2O)0.5 (3), in the present contribution. The non-covalent intermolecular contacts, such as π-π stacking interactions and/or hydrogen bonds, are presented in these complexes, and their effects on the overall supramolecular architectures are discussed in detail.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and general methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">With the exception of the bridging ligand 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), which was synthesized according to reported literature procedure , all of the starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and used as received. Fourier transform (FT)-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

With the exception of the bridging ligand 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), which was synthesized according to reported literature procedure , all of the starting materials and solvents were obtained commercially and used as received. Fourier transform (FT)-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a FT-IR 170SX (Nicolet) spectrometer. Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer.

<ce:section-title>Crystallographic data collection and structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were performed on a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam. The data collections were performed with Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) by <ce:italic>ϖ</ce:italic> scan mode in the range of 2.17<<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic><25.03° (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 2.73<<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic><25.02° (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and 2.70<<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic><25.03° (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. All data were corrected by semi-empirical method using <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program. The program <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps>
 was used for integration of the diffraction profiles.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data collection and structure determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study of complexes 1-3 were performed on a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam. The data collections were performed with MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) by ϖ scan mode in the range of 2.17<θ<25.03° (for 1), 2.73<θ<25.02° (for 2) and 2.70<θ<25.03° (for 3) at 293(2)K. All data were corrected by semi-empirical method using sadabs program. The program saint  was used for integration of the diffraction profiles.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">All structures were solved by direct methods using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps> program of the <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>-97 package and refined with <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>
. Metal atoms in all complexes were located from the <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinements were performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed in the calculated sites and included in the final refinement in the riding model approximation with displacement parameters derived from the parent atoms to which they were bonded. The ratios of minimum to maximum apparent transmission are 0.9069 (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 0.9358 (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and 0.8830 (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), respectively. Molecular graphics were drawn with the program package XP. Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor>, and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All structures were solved by direct methods using shelxs program of the shelxtl-97 package and refined with shelxl . Metal atoms in all complexes were located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinements were performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed in the calculated sites and included in the final refinement in the riding model approximation with displacement parameters derived from the parent atoms to which they were bonded. The ratios of minimum to maximum apparent transmission are 0.9069 (for 1), 0.9358 (for 2), and 0.8830 (for 3), respectively. Molecular graphics were drawn with the program package XP. Further crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of complexes 1-3 are summarized in  , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations in  , respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and general characterization of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Ligand L is very soluble in common polar organic solvents (such as CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN etc.), so that crystallization of its complexes with inorganic metal salts occurs readily. As stated above, single crystals of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared by the reactions of corresponding metal salt and L in 1:2 molar ratio through slow evaporation of the solvent. Additionally, the final product for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was independent to the quantity of NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was obtained as crystalline polymeric compound in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> mixed solvent system by combination of L with AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> in 1:1 molar ratio through diffusion. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are air stable and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and general characterization of complexes 1-3 

Ligand L is very soluble in common polar organic solvents (such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, CH3OH and CH3CN etc.), so that crystallization of its complexes with inorganic metal salts occurs readily. As stated above, single crystals of complexes 1 and 2 were prepared by the reactions of corresponding metal salt and L in 1:2 molar ratio through slow evaporation of the solvent. Additionally, the final product for 2 was independent to the quantity of NH4SCN. Complex 3 was obtained as crystalline polymeric compound in CH3OH/CHCl3 mixed solvent system by combination of L with AgBF4 in 1:1 molar ratio through diffusion. Compounds 1-3 are air stable and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The IR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibration of the aromatic rings in the 1400–1600 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region. A strong and broad band centered around 3455 (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 3355 (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> can be assignable to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">O–H</ce:inf> stretch of the coordinated water molecules, and that around 3440 (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">O–H</ce:inf> stretch of the lattice aqua or CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH solvents. The characteristic absorption band with medium intensity of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">CN</ce:inf>) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> appears at 2220 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Additionally, the IR spectrum for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays the very strong absorption band of the NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions at 2077 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of complexes 1-3 show absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibration of the aromatic rings in the 1400-1600 cm-1 region. A strong and broad band centered around 3455 (for 1) and 3355 (for 2)cm-1 can be assignable to the ν O-H stretch of the coordinated water molecules, and that around 3440 (for 3) to the ν O-H stretch of the lattice aqua or CH3OH solvents. The characteristic absorption band with medium intensity of CH3CN (ν CN) in 1 appears at 2220 cm-1. Additionally, the IR spectrum for 2 displays the very strong absorption band of the NCS- anions at 2077 cm-1.

<ce:section-title>Description of the crystal structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>[Mn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of a discrete centrosymmetrical [Mn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, two ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, and two lattice CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules. The crystal structure of the cationic mononuclear unit is depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>. The Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is located at a crystallographic inversion center, and six-coordinated to two aqua and two CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two L ligands in the axial positions. The coordination geometry of the metal center can be described as a slightly distorted octahedron with the <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> N–Mn–N and N–Mn–O angles being in the range of 87.48(15)–92.52(15)°. The two pyridine rings within each ligand form the dihedral angles of 3.1 and 1.3°, respectively, with the central oxadiazole plane, and the dihedral angle of 2.5° with each other. In addition, it should be noted that two similar, but crystallographically independent molecules were observed in this structure. They have similar mononuclear motifs with only slight difference in bond distances and angles ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures of complexes 1-3 

 [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2  (1). Complex 1 consists of a discrete centrosymmetrical [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2]2+, two ClO4 - anions, and two lattice CH3CN molecules. The crystal structure of the cationic mononuclear unit is depicted in  . The MnII ion is located at a crystallographic inversion center, and six-coordinated to two aqua and two CH3CN molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two L ligands in the axial positions. The coordination geometry of the metal center can be described as a slightly distorted octahedron with the cis N-Mn-N and N-Mn-O angles being in the range of 87.48(15)-92.52(15)°. The two pyridine rings within each ligand form the dihedral angles of 3.1 and 1.3°, respectively, with the central oxadiazole plane, and the dihedral angle of 2.5° with each other. In addition, it should be noted that two similar, but crystallographically independent molecules were observed in this structure. They have similar mononuclear motifs with only slight difference in bond distances and angles ().

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Herein the L ligand uses only one of the pyridyl nitrogen atoms to bind to the metal center. The other uncoordinated pyridyl nitrogen serves as the hydrogen-bonding acceptor of the coordinated aqua molecule of another mononuclear cation with the O⋯N distance of 2.731<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å . Such hydrogen bonds extend the mononuclear units to 1D chains with loop-like links (). There also exist intra-chain aromatic stacking interaction between the coordinated pyridyl ring and the adjacent uncoordinated case in each loop, with the inter-planar separation of 3.415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (center-to-center separation=3.722<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . Furthermore, these 1D chains are stacked parallel to generate a 2D undulating sheet along <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane through the inter-chain aromatic interaction between the oxadiazole ring and the coordinated pyridyl ring. The inter-planar and center-to-center separations here are 3.302 and 3.655<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Therefore, in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the hydrogen bond and π–π stacking interactions play an influential role in expanding the mononuclear units to 2D layers, among which lie the disordered ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and lattice CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules.</ce:para>

The other uncoordinated pyridyl nitrogen serves as the hydrogen-bonding acceptor of the coordinated aqua molecule of another mononuclear cation with the O⋯N distance of 2.731Å . Such hydrogen bonds extend the mononuclear units to 1D chains with loop-like links (). There also exist intra-chain aromatic stacking interaction between the coordinated pyridyl ring and the adjacent uncoordinated case in each loop, with the inter-planar separation of 3.415Å (center-to-center separation=3.722Å) . Furthermore, these 1D chains are stacked parallel to generate a 2D undulating sheet along ac plane through the inter-chain aromatic interaction between the oxadiazole ring and the coordinated pyridyl ring. The inter-planar and center-to-center separations here are 3.302 and 3.655Å, respectively. Therefore, in complex 1, the hydrogen bond and π-π stacking interactions play an influential role in expanding the mononuclear units to 2D layers, among which lie the disordered ClO4 - anions and lattice CH3CN molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Using L to react with Cu(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in a CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O medium (even if in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O system just as the preparation procedure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), a two-fold interpenetrated diamondoid 3D framework was afforded , whose extended structure contrasts greatly with that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This discrepancy suggests that the nature of the metal ions highly influences the structural topologies of such coordination frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Using L to react with Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in a CH3OH/H2O medium (even if in CH3CN/H2O system just as the preparation procedure of 1), a two-fold interpenetrated diamondoid 3D framework was afforded , whose extended structure contrasts greatly with that of 1. This discrepancy suggests that the nature of the metal ions highly influences the structural topologies of such coordination frameworks.

elements.clean_text: [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2). The molecular structure of the neutral mononuclear compound 2 is depicted in  . The coordination environment of FeII ion is similar to that of MnII in 1. Each metal center is in an elongated octahedral environment composed of two nitrogen atoms from two NSC- groups (Fe-NNCS=2.139(3)Å) and two aqua oxygen atoms (Fe-O=2.208(2)Å) in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Fe-Npy=2.353(2)Å) in the axial positions. The cis N-Fe-N and N-Fe-O angles are in the range of 89.38(10)-90.62(10)° as listed in . The NSC- anions are coordinated to FeII in a monodentate terminal mode with the angles of 166.2(3)° for Fe(1)-N(5)-C(13) and 178.7(3)° for N(5)-C(13)-S(1). Two pyridyl rings within each L molecule deviate by 3.3° from co-planarity, and form the dihedral angles of 3.7 and 1.2°, respectively, with the central oxadiazole plane.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a pair of centrosymmetrically related L ligands coordinate to the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center in monodentate fashion to form the basal mononuclear unit. The uncoordinated pyridine and oxadiazole rings participate in the hydrogen bonds with the coordinated aqua molecules, which bind the mononuclear molecules to form a 2D layer structure. The O(2)⋯N(2) and O(2)⋯N(4) separations are 2.901 and 2.795<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, and the corresponding O(2)–H(1)⋯N(2) and O(2)–H(2)⋯N(4) angles are 159.5 and 159.6°. Moreover, the pyridyl rings of the ligands are involved in the interlayer face-to-face aromatic stacking interactions with the closest separation of 3.452<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (center-to-center distance=3.690<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), through which the 2D layers are stacked parallel along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction to generate a 3D supramolecular structure ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 2, a pair of centrosymmetrically related L ligands coordinate to the FeII center in monodentate fashion to form the basal mononuclear unit. The uncoordinated pyridine and oxadiazole rings participate in the hydrogen bonds with the coordinated aqua molecules, which bind the mononuclear molecules to form a 2D layer structure. The O(2)⋯N(2) and O(2)⋯N(4) separations are 2.901 and 2.795Å, respectively, and the corresponding O(2)-H(1)⋯N(2) and O(2)-H(2)⋯N(4) angles are 159.5 and 159.6°. Moreover, the pyridyl rings of the ligands are involved in the interlayer face-to-face aromatic stacking interactions with the closest separation of 3.452Å (center-to-center distance=3.690Å), through which the 2D layers are stacked parallel along a direction to generate a 3D supramolecular structure ().

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It is noteworthy that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the first Fe<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> coordination compound based on the series of angular dipyridyl-donor ligands. We have prepared three analogous complexes, [M(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NSC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (M=Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> or Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>), in the same synthetic method . These results indicate such mononuclear structure is thermodynamically stable and independent to the variety of the metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that complex 2 is the first FeII coordination compound based on the series of angular dipyridyl-donor ligands. We have prepared three analogous complexes, [M(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (M=CdII, MnII or CoII), in the same synthetic method . These results indicate such mononuclear structure is thermodynamically stable and independent to the variety of the metal ions.

<ce:italic>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> consists of 1D cationic chains, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH and aqua molecules. There are two independent Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> centers [Ag(1) and Ag(2)] bridged by the L ligand in the asymmetric unit ()<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. Each Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> center is in a linear coordination environment (N–Ag(1)–N=175.3(4), N–Ag(2)–N=171.8(4)°) and coordinates to two pyridyl N atoms (Ag(1)–N: 2.127(9) and 2.151(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Ag(2)–N: 2.130(9) and 2.164(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) from distinct bridging ligands. The L ligand links two Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> centers in bidentate bridging mode with two pyridyl N donors to form an infinite chain. Two L molecules around the metal center are different in structural geometry. Two pyridine rings within one L form the dihedral angles of 6.1 and 21.4°, respectively, with the oxadiazole plane, and the dihedral angle of 25.7° with each other. The corresponding values for the other L molecule are 5.7, 8.2 and 13.6°, respectively. The angle between the central oxadiazole ring and two N donors of the 4-pyridyl rings in each L molecule is 138.8 or 139.7°, resulting in a sinusoidal chain motif. The separation of the ligand-bridging Ag⋯Ag contact is 13.936<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>

The corresponding values for the other L molecule are 5.7, 8.2 and 13.6°, respectively. The angle between the central oxadiazole ring and two N donors of the 4-pyridyl rings in each L molecule is 138.8 or 139.7°, resulting in a sinusoidal chain motif. The separation of the ligand-bridging Ag⋯Ag contact is 13.936Å.

<ce:para view="all">Of further interest, these infinite chains are arranged in a parallel fashion and form an undulating layer (). The neighboring chains are anti-parallel to each other with the nearest inter-chain Ag⋯Ag distance of 3.879<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. One of the two pyridyl rings around each Ag(1) or Ag(2) center is involved in the π–π stacking interaction with one oxadiazole ring in the other anti-parallel chain (inter-planar separation=3.042/3.318<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, center-to-center separation=3.706/3.657<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). These aromatic interactions extend the 1D chains to result in a 2D supramolecular layer, which are further stacked in an offset fashion with ABAB sequence. The BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and solvent guest molecules are incorporated in the interlayer regions.</ce:para>

These aromatic interactions extend the 1D chains to result in a 2D supramolecular layer, which are further stacked in an offset fashion with ABAB sequence. elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Although it has been well known that hydrogen bonding interactions are usually effective in extending the dimensions of a supramolecular network, however, the organic ligands involved in the nucleation process use both coordination and π–π stacking interactions to build up the supramolecular framework, is still not well documented. In the structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the significant aromatic staking interactions do play a critical role in expanding the dimensionality of the frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Although it has been well known that hydrogen bonding interactions are usually effective in extending the dimensions of a supramolecular network, however, the organic ligands involved in the nucleation process use both coordination and π-π stacking interactions to build up the supramolecular framework, is still not well documented. In the structures of complexes 1-3, the significant aromatic staking interactions do play a critical role in expanding the dimensionality of the frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Three metal complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have been prepared by means of self-assemblies of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> salts and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. The resultant structures of these complexes are profoundly influenced by π–π stacking interactions and/or hydrogen bonds, which will provide interesting examples for supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three metal complexes 1-3 have been prepared by means of self-assemblies of MnII, FeII, AgI salts and 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L), and structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction analyses. The resultant structures of these complexes are profoundly influenced by π-π stacking interactions and/or hydrogen bonds, which will provide interesting examples for supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering.

Synthesis of complexes 1-3 

 [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2  (1). A solution of L (22 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH3CN (15 ml) was added to an aqueous solution (10 ml) of Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (36 mg, 0.1 mmol). After ca. 30 min of vigorous mixing, the solution was filtered and left to stand at room temperature. Light-yellow prismatic single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by evaporation of the solvent within 1 week. Yield: 65%. Found: C, 42.4; H, 3.8; N, 18.3%. Calc. for C32H32Cl2MnN12O12: C, 42.6; H, 3.6; N, 18.6%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3455b, 3067s, 2220m, 1662m, 1616m, 1570m, 1489m, 1423s, 1283m, 1219m, 1108vs, 1063s, 1008m, 842m, 723s, 626m, 504m.

 [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2). A solution of an excess of NH4SCN (24 mg, 0.3 mmol) in H2O (10 ml) was added to a CH3CN/CHCl3 solution (15 ml) containing FeCl2⋅4H2O (20 mg, 0.1 mmol) and L (44 mg, 0.2 mmol) in 1:2 molar ratio. After ca. 30 min of vigorous mixing under refluxing, the reaction mixture was filtered and left to stand at room temperature. Yellow block single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent within 2 weeks. Yield: 70%. Found: C, 47.9; H, 3.2; N, 20.9%. Calc. for C26H20FeN10O4S2: C, 47.6; H, 3.1; N, 21.3%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3355b, 3088w, 3038w, 2077vs, 1955w, 1613s, 1566s, 1541s, 1486s, 1422s, 1370w, 1335m, 1322w, 1275m, 1230w, 1218s, 1124m, 1107w, 1064s, 1006s, 966m, 840s, 744s, 723vs, 710s, 695s.

 [Ag2(L)2](BF4)2(CH3OH)0.5(H2O)0.5  (3). A solution of AgBF4 (19 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (10 ml) was carefully layered on top of a CHCl3 solution (10 ml) of L (22 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a test-tube. After ca. 2 weeks at room temperature, colorless single crystals appeared at the boundary between CH3OH and CHCl3. Yield: 50%. Found: C, 33.7; H, 2.6; N, 13.3%. Calc. for C24.5H19Ag2B2F8N8O3: C, 34.1; H, 2.2; N, 13.0%. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3440b, 3104m, 3062w, 1619s, 1567s, 1542s, 1488s, 1429s, 1341w, 1285m, 1224m, 1073vs, 1022vs, 971m, 845s, 747s, 731s, 716s, 705m, 551w, 521m, 506w, 411w.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new metal-organic supramolecular complexes based on the linking unit 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (L) and inorganic MnII, FeII, AgI salts have been prepared and structurally determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis. Using L to react with Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O yielded a mononuclear molecule, [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2 (1) (triclinic, P-1, a=8.790(4)Å, b=10.227(4)Å, c=23.255(10)Å, α=89.371(8)°, β=82.980(8)°, γ=88.621(8)°, Z=2), in which the hydrogen bonding and π-π aromatic stacking interactions extend the complex molecules to result in a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular network. Reaction of L and FeCl2⋅4H2O, in the presence of NH4SCN, afforded another mononuclear complex, [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2) (triclinic, P-1, a=7.985(3)Å, b=8.657(3)Å, c=11.334(4)Å, α=94.243(6)°, β=109.989(7)°, γ=94.413(7)°, Z=1). A 3D framework is observed through hydrogen bonds and π-π stacking co-affections between the complex molecules. Additionally, a 1D coordination polymer, [Ag2(L)2](BF4)2(CH3OH)0.5(H2O)0.5 (3) (triclinic, P-1, a=8.321(3)Å, b=13.926(5)Å, c=14.229(5)Å, α=70.801(7)°, β=77.216(7)°, γ=81.299(7)°, Z=2) was obtained when AgBF4 was used in the above reaction. The structure of 3 contains significant aromatic interactions, which bind the infinite chains together to form a 2D layer network.

Description of the crystal structures of complexes 1-3 

 [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2(CH3CN)2  (1). Complex 1 consists of a discrete centrosymmetrical [Mn(L)2(H2O)2(CH3CN)2]2+, two ClO4 - anions, and two lattice CH3CN molecules. The crystal structure of the cationic mononuclear unit is depicted in  . The MnII ion is located at a crystallographic inversion center, and six-coordinated to two aqua and two CH3CN molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two L ligands in the axial positions. The coordination geometry of the metal center can be described as a slightly distorted octahedron with the cis N-Mn-N and N-Mn-O angles being in the range of 87.48(15)-92.52(15)°. The two pyridine rings within each ligand form the dihedral angles of 3.1 and 1.3°, respectively, with the central oxadiazole plane, and the dihedral angle of 2.5° with each other. In addition, it should be noted that two similar, but crystallographically independent molecules were observed in this structure. They have similar mononuclear motifs with only slight difference in bond distances and angles ().

 [Fe(L)2(NSC)2(H2O)2] (2). The molecular structure of the neutral mononuclear compound 2 is depicted in  . The coordination environment of FeII ion is similar to that of MnII in 1. Each metal center is in an elongated octahedral environment composed of two nitrogen atoms from two NSC- groups (Fe-NNCS=2.139(3)Å) and two aqua oxygen atoms (Fe-O=2.208(2)Å) in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two L ligands (Fe-Npy=2.353(2)Å) in the axial positions. The cis N-Fe-N and N-Fe-O angles are in the range of 89.38(10)-90.62(10)° as listed in . The NSC- anions are coordinated to FeII in a monodentate terminal mode with the angles of 166.2(3)° for Fe(1)-N(5)-C(13) and 178.7(3)° for N(5)-C(13)-S(1). Two pyridyl rings within each L molecule deviate by 3.3° from co-planarity, and form the dihedral angles of 3.7 and 1.2°, respectively, with the central oxadiazole plane.

 [Ag2(L)2](BF4)2(CH3OH)0.5(H2O)0.5  (3). The structure of 3 consists of 1D cationic chains, BF4 - anions, CH3OH and aqua molecules. There are two independent AgI centers [Ag(1) and Ag(2)] bridged by the L ligand in the asymmetric unit (). Each AgI center is in a linear coordination environment (N-Ag(1)-N=175.3(4), N-Ag(2)-N=171.8(4)°) and coordinates to two pyridyl N atoms (Ag(1)-N: 2.127(9) and 2.151(9)Å; Ag(2)-N: 2.130(9) and 2.164(9)Å) from distinct bridging ligands. The L ligand links two AgI centers in bidentate bridging mode with two pyridyl N donors to form an infinite chain. Two L molecules around the metal center are different in structural geometry. Two pyridine rings within one L form the dihedral angles of 6.1 and 21.4°, respectively, with the oxadiazole plane, and the dihedral angle of 25.7° with each other. The corresponding values for the other L molecule are 5.7, 8.2 and 13.6°, respectively. The angle between the central oxadiazole ring and two N donors of the 4-pyridyl rings in each L molecule is 138.8 or 139.7°, resulting in a sinusoidal chain motif. The separation of the ligand-bridging Ag⋯Ag contact is 13.936Å.
